members.name: L. Anthony Beall
members.bio: Tony is a licensed attorney and has been practicing law in California for 25 years. As a real estate transactional attorney, he has developed an in-depth knowledge and special expertise in legal matters relating to public and private financing, as well as the real estate development and land-use planning process. Tony is an attorney with the international law firm of Troutman Pepper Locke and has practiced law in some of the largest and most sophisticated private law firms in the State of California. He has also served as Chief Counsel for one of the largest providers of multifamily financing throughout the United States. As a law school graduate and as a Political Science major, Tony developed a thorough understanding and respect for our governmental institutions and the manner in which they were designed to function for the benefit of all citizens. Tony has received diplomas from: City Council Member for Rancho Santa Margarita since 2004

members.name: Anne D. Figueroa
members.bio: Anne Figueroa is a 27-year resident of Rancho Santa Margarita. She and her husband, Dan, raised their three children here in our city while they attended both public and private schools. Anne has owned her own design business for the past 29 years and has won numerous design awards. Anne served as a Rancho Santa Margarita Planning Commissioner for three years and also served as Planning Commissioner Chair for one year.  Anne was elected to the Rancho Santa Margarita City Council in November 2018. Anne served as Mayor Pro Tempore in 2021 and as Mayor in 2022. Anne is also currently serving as the District Director for Assemblywoman Kate Sanchez of the 71st Assembly District, State of California.

members.name: Bradley J. McGirr
members.bio: After years of service to the community, Brad was appointed to the Rancho Santa Margarita Planning Commission in December 2009 and served as the Vice Chair in 2012. He was also appointed as a member of the City’s Economic Development Committee and the Business Attraction Working Group. On November 6, 2012, Brad was elected to the Rancho Santa Margarita City Council, serving as Mayor Pro Tempore in 2014 and as Mayor in 2015. Brad again served as Mayor in 2020 and guided our city in this capacity at the height of the COVID pandemic. Brad was our city’s Mayor Pro Tempore in 2024 and 2025 and proudly serves as a member of the Board of Directors for the Orange County Fire Authority.

members.name: Jerry Holloway
members.bio: Dean of Students - Santa Margarita Catholic High School Social Studies Teacher - Santa Margarita Catholic High School Administration of Justice Instructor - Irvine Valley College

members.name: Keri Lynn Baert
members.bio: Keri has been a resident of Rancho Santa Margarita since 2002 and has dedicated herself to serving the community through various volunteer roles. She has been actively involved with local organizations and has supported her children’s education by volunteering in school parent organizations, scouting groups, and sports teams. Her work with the PTA sparked a deep passion for advocacy, leading her to travel to Sacramento to engage with lawmakers on issues such as student mental health and school funding. In January 2020, Keri authored a resolution at the California State PTA convention that called for enhanced mental health services for youth, including increasing the number of school counselors at every level. Her tireless volunteer efforts have earned her several accolades, including the Presidential Service Gold Award, the Fourth District PTA Advocacy Award, and the SVUSD Community Volunteer Recognition Award. Trabuco Hills PTSA - President, EVP, VP of Advocacy Rancho Santa Margarita Intermediate PTSO - President, Executive Board Member

members.name: Valerie Amezcua
members.bio: Mayor Amezcua is the first female Mayor in the City of Santa Ana's 153-year history. Mayor Amezcua has served as a member of the Santa Ana Unified School District (SAUSD) Governing Board since 2014. She has served as the Board's President or Vice President for five of the past eight years. Over the course of her two terms on the School Board, she has implemented common sense reforms to improve graduation rates, increase campus safety and expand parent involvement. She is a strong advocate for community health access, and played a key role in the expansion of mental health services throughout SAUSD. She also led the effort to get additional training for SAUSD Police Officers to improve relationships with students and community members, implementing a positive community-based approach to campus safety. Mayor Amezcua is a mentor, a bridge builder, and a collaborator who understands the value of partnerships to the long-term success of our neighborhoods and community-at-large. Having achieved progress in her efforts on behalf of Santa Ana's youth, Mayor Amezcua brings her leadership, vision, and passion for public service to the work of city government. She is committed to creating a more prosperous and sustainable future for Orange County's second most populated city.

members.name: David Penaloza
members.bio: Councilmember David Penaloza, born and raised in Santa Ana, is a lifetime resident of the city. A product of the Santa Ana Unified School District, he attended Washington Elementary (1999), MacArthur Fundamental (2002), and Saddleback High School (2006). After attending Santa Ana College, he was accepted to California State University, Los Angeles and graduated in 2011 with a Bachelor of Arts degree in English. Councilmember Penaloza remains active in his community by supporting Santa Ana youth through his volunteer work at his local church. During his college career, Councilmember Penaloza overcame several obstacles, including paying tuition and supporting his mother financially. While in college, he took acting classes as a hobby, which eventually led him to be booked on numerous national commercials. His success qualified him membership into SAG-AFTRA, the most distinguished performers' union in the world. In 2008, Councilmember Penaloza worked as a part-time office clerk at Color Science, Inc., a local company specializing in compounding raw materials and resins to produce plastic. He was a key player in the ISO accreditation of the company, which allowed him to move up to his current position as Senior Regulatory Engineer. In 2018, Councilmember Penaloza was inspired by the students he was tutoring and the neglect he witnessed firsthand in Santa Ana. Penaloza had a strong desire to give back to the only place he has called home. For these reasons, he decided to run for Santa Ana City Council. Personally knocking on over 6,000 doors throughout Santa Ana, Councilmember Penaloza won 27 percent of the vote in a crowded field of six candidates, earning him a seat on the Santa Ana City Council to represent Ward 2. He was sworn in on December 11, 2018.

members.name: Thai Viet Phan
members.bio: Councilmember Thai Viet Phan is proud to be the first Vietnamese American and first Asian woman to serve as a Santa Ana Councilmember. She was born near a refugee camp in Thailand after her parents fled the devastation of the Vietnam War. They settled in Santa Ana in 1989 after months of living in camps in Thailand and the Philippines. Tragically, her father succumbed to brain cancer soon after arriving in the States. Councilmember Phan's mother worked as a babysitter watching neighborhood kids, and they lived in garages and make-shift bedrooms with other families to make ends meet. Like many first-generation immigrant families fleeing conflict and oppression, they were no strangers to poverty. Despite the struggle of growing up with few resources and reliant on the social safety net, Councilmember Phan excelled in the classroom. She attended local public schools—all in the Garden Grove Unified School District, including Morningside, Hazard, Heritage, Skylark, and Simmons Elementary Schools and was the first in her family to graduate high school (Los Amigos High School—2006). She completed her Bachelor of Arts in Communication Studies at the University of California Los Angeles and later graduated from the University of Southern California with a dual Law/Master of Public Policy degree. Throughout college and graduate school, Councilmember Phan worked multiple part-time jobs to supplement her student loans and afford housing and tuition, including serving burgers as an In-N-Out Burger Associate for six years. Today, Thai works as a City Attorney and provides legal advice and counsel to cities and other public agencies throughout Southern California. She previously served as a member of the Santa Ana Planning Commission, where she advised the City Council and helped oversee an array of critical issues, including housing, land use, and small business development. Thai currently serves on the Board of Directors of both the Vietnamese American Bar Association of Southern California and the Heritage Museum of Orange County. She also serves on the Leadership, Equity, Advocacy, & Diversity Advisory Board for the Rancho Santiago Community College District.

members.name: Benjamin Vazquez
members.bio: Councilmember Vazquez is a teacher at Valley High School, a cultural worker at El Centro Cultural de Mexico, and a proud homeowner in the Heninger Park neighborhood. Councilmember Vazquez is fully invested in his community and in the future of Santa Ana. He was born to working class immigrant parents and was raised on Center Street. Councilmember Vazquez attended Santa Ana Unified School District schools, Santa Ana College, earned a Bachelor's degree at Cal State Long Beach, and a Master's degree from UCLA. Councilmember Vazquez is now proudly working alongside four siblings and two nieces at Santa Ana Unified School District. Giving back to Santa Ana youth and community is not just his passion—it is a shared family goal. As a member of the City Council, Councilmember Vazquez's focus will be on making sure our limited citywide resources benefit working class families and improve quality of life for all Santa Ana residents. Our City budgets, policies, and resources need to be centered on nurturing the families and communities of our city, instead of special interest groups. Councilmember Vazquez believes that our City's plan and budgets need to reflect a vision that prioritizes working class families.

members.name: Jessie Lopez
members.bio: Born and raised in Santa Ana, Jessie experienced her upbringing in a working-class household. Jessie and her siblings attended Hoover Elementary, Willard Intermediate and Santa Ana High School. Jessie continued her post-secondary educational career by pursuing an A.A. at Santa Ana College and a B.A. in Sociology at California State University, Long Beach. Throughout her time in college, Jessie worked two jobs to support herself financially through school. As an undergraduate student, she helped organize students and led campaigns to address sexual assault on campus and supported efforts in making higher education more accessible for individuals such as herself. She continued her advocacy alongside community groups in her hometown to fight for equity, accountability and transparency. Jessie now works as a community health worker where she works towards improving the quality of life and health of low-income, uninsured, under-served people, regardless of status, in her community. In March 2020, Jessie was elected by the working families of the 68th Assembly District to help represent their concerns as a central committee member within the Democratic Party of Orange County. Jessie is honored to represent Ward 3 and to serve the community that raised her. She is a firm believer in civic engagement, the right to equal treatment and opportunity, and is passionate about empowering community participation. Jessie is an advocate for all Santa Ana families, and with a demonstrated record of community leadership, she will provide effective representation for Santa Ana. Jessie Lopez is an advocate and organizer at heart.

members.name: Phil Bacerra
members.bio: Councilmember Phil Bacerra was elected to the Santa Ana City Council in November 2019 to represent Ward 4. Councilmember Bacerra is the son of a union grocery store manager and a waitress. He was born and raised in Orange County, where he attended local schools and worked as a busboy at his uncle's restaurant in Santa Ana – Pop's Cafe. Graduating from the University of Southern California with a Bachelor of Science degree in Urban Planning, Councilmember Bacerra went on to work for various city government agencies, including the city of Los Angeles. He has been using that city government experience to help small businesses succeed and increase access to high-quality housing.

members.name: Johnathan Ryan Hernandez
members.bio: Councilmember Johnathan Ryan Hernandez was born and raised in Santa Ana and is a lifetime resident of the Artesia Pilar neighborhood. He is proud of his family's deep roots in Santa Ana and is honored to raise his daughter in the very community his family has called home for five generations and counting. Councilmember Hernandez is a product of Santa Ana Unified School District (SAUSD) education system and attended Fremont Elementary, Spurgeon Intermediate, and Santa Ana High School. He was raised by the combined effort of a hard-working single mother and his grandparents. Councilmember Hernandez's grandfather, Enrique was a member of the Laborers International Union, Local 652 and was an upstanding member for over 43 years. His grandparents, Enrique and Indelisa, migrated to Santa Ana from Guadalajara, Mexico in the late 1950s. Councilmember Hernandez grew up in Artesia Pilar amidst a challenging decade for the neighborhood in the 1990s. Born in the summer of '92, he lived houses away from El Salvador Park and was a witness to numerous tragedies. Like many multi-generational Chicano families, he saw his family members and friends fall through the cracks and end up in the prison system. As a result of his upbringing by the age of 14 Councilmember Hernandez began to organize political events with youth in his community. By the time he was 23, he began working with youth in the community, offering boxing, music, and art programs to at-promise youth. In 2015, Councilmember Hernandez was part of The Mixed Martial Arts Association (MMAFA), a collective of Mixed Martial Arts (MMA) athletes that worked to introduce legislation that would extend protections from the sport of boxing to the sport of MMA. In May 2015, a bill was introduced to Congress by Markwayne Mullin, a politician and former mixed martial artist, to extend the Ali Act to MMA.

members.name: David J. Shawver
members.bio: Mayor David John Shawver has lived in the Stanton community for 47 years, where he and his wife Jennifer raised their family of David, Matthew, Stephanie, Katrina and Joseph. Today three still live in Stanton and the grandkids attend local schools. Mayor Shawver attended the University of the Pacific on an athletic scholarship playing both football and baseball. After earning a Bachelor of Arts degree in Kinesiology, with minors in Geology and Education, he was awarded an academic graduate fellowship teaching at the university and received his master’s degree in Kinesiology, with a minor in Education. Mayor Shawver has taught for 42 years in the Long Beach Unified School District, at Long Beach City College, and Hope International University in Fullerton. In addition, he has coached football, wrestling, baseball, girls’ softball, girls' cross country, and was the medical athletic trainer at both the high school and collegiate levels. Mayor Shawver currently serves Stanton as Vice-Chair of the Orange County Sanitation District (OCSD), Executive Board Member of the Orange County Fire Authority (OCFA), Board Member and Past Chairman of Orange County Waste & Recycling (OCWR), Past Chairman and Board Member of the Public Cable Television Authority (PCTA), Chairman of the Stanton Oversight Board on Redevelopment, and Member of the Stanton Development Committee, Public Finance Committee, and Public Housing Authority. He also represents Stanton on the Association of California Cities

members.name: Gary Taylor
members.bio: Mr. Gary Taylor grew up in Anaheim and attended local schools. He graduated from Cal State Fullerton with a BA and later from Webster University in Irvine with a MA in Management. Mr. Taylor, his wife Lynne, and two sons moved to Stanton in 1985. He served on the Stanton Planning Commission from June of 2012 and was elected to the City Council to serve District 3 in November of 2018. Mr. Taylor's priorities include improving public safety, promoting the development of Beach Boulevard, and listening to and being responsive to Stanton residents.

members.name: Victor Barrios
members.bio: Victor Barrios was born in the City of Stanton, and he attended local schools in the area. He has a Bachelor of Science in Kinesiology from Cal State Fullerton, Masters in Special Education from National University, Credential Ed Specialist Credential and a Single Subject Credential. He has taught multiple subjects throughout his teaching career while making sure he meets the needs of all his students. He spent his first ten years of teaching for the Anaheim Union High School District. Currently he is teaching Special Education Classes for high school students. As a teacher he promotes perseverance and motivates his students to be a productive citizen in their community. He has also been active in his community, for many years in the city and surrounding areas he coaches baseball, basketball, softball and soccer. He has met many great young men and women through coaching and teaching, while having a positive impact on their lives.

members.name: John D. Warren
members.bio: John Douglas Warren is a third-generation Stanton resident and a proud graduate of local public schools, having attended Bryant Elementary, Alamitos Intermediate, and Rancho Alamitos High School. His commitment to public service began with his Eagle Scout project, marking the start of a lasting dedication to his hometown. John earned a degree in Political Science from Cypress College and later graduated Magna Cum Laude from California State University, Fullerton (CSUF) with a Bachelor's in Public Administration, where he was also inducted into Pi Alpha Alpha and Pi Sigma Alpha, the national honor societies for Public Administration and Political Science. His early civic involvement in Stanton included serving on the Stanton 60th Anniversary Committee and the Car Show Committee, helping foster community spirit through public events. He later served eight years on the Parks, Recreation, and Community Services Commission, including five years as Chair, contributing to Stanton's quality-of-life programs and recreational planning.

members.name: Austin Lumbard
members.bio: Mayor Austin Lumbard, elected to City Council in 2018 and elected as Mayor in 2022, was born and raised in Orange County and is a long-time Tustin resident.  His priorities while on City Council include: Mayor Lumbard has served the community in a variety of roles.  He currently represents Tustin on the Orange County Fire Authority and is an alternate representative to the Orange County Sanitation District and the Water Advisory Committee of Orange County.  Mayor Lumbard previously served on the Foothill/Eastern Transportation Corridor Agencies, the Newport Bay Watershed Executive Committee, the Santa Ana River Flood Protection Agency, and the Airport Land Use Commission for Orange County. Prior to being elected to City Council, Mayor Lumbard served six years on Tustin’s Planning Commission, twice as Commission Chair.  He also served for many years as a reserve deputy with the Orange County Sheriff’s Department.  This experience helped shape his passion for keeping all Tustin residents safe.

members.name: Ray Schnell
members.bio: Mayor Pro Tem Ray Schnell, elected to office in November 2022, has lived in Orange County for 20 years and is a long-time Tustin resident. His priorities while on City Council include keeping Tustin: Accountable (honest, ethical, and transparent government) Affordable & Prosperous (preserving the economic vitality of Tustin.

members.name: John Nielsen
members.bio: Council Member John Nielsen was elected to the City Council originally in 2008, was re-elected in 2012 and served through 2016. He also served as Mayor in 2012 and in 2016. During this time on the City Council John served as the Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Orange County Sanitation District from 2015 to 2016, and on the Board from 2010 to 2016. He also served as Regional Council Member for District 17 representing the Cities of Tustin, Orange and Villa Park on the Board for the Southern California Association of Governments from 2009 to 2016. John also served on the Board of Directors for the Orange County Fire Authority in 2010. Prior to being elected to the City Council he served on the Tustin Planning Commission from 2002 to 2008. Subsequent to his service on the Tustin City Council John was elected to the Board of Directors for the East Orange County Water District representing District 4 in 2022. In November of 2024 Council Member Nielsen was again elected to the Tustin City Council representing District 2.

members.name: Lee K. Fink
members.bio: Council Member Lee Fink, elected in November 2024, is a Tustin native, attorney, and longtime community volunteer. His priorities on the City Council focus on: Developing the Local Economy for the Future, including providing abundant housing and business development in Tustin Keeping the community safe and healthy, including ensuring public safety, addressing homelessness, and

members.name: Ryan Gallagher
members.bio: Mayor Pro Tem Ryan Gallagher, elected to City Council in 2020, was born and raised in Southern California and is a passionate advocate for fiscally responsible government, innovation, and supporting a vibrant local community in Tustin. His priorities while on City Council include Mayor Pro Tem Gallagher represents the City of Tustin as Vice-Chair of the Orange County Sanitation District Board, and also serves as a member of the Water Advisory Committee of Orange County and Newport Bay Watershed Executive Committee (alternate). Prior to joining the City Council, Ryan proudly served the community through his role on the Tustin Planning Commission.

members.name: Chi Charlie Nguyen
members.bio: Mayor Nguyen was first elected in 2016 to serve on the Midway City Sanitary Board and is proud to be serving as the Board President. He was then elected as a City Council Member in November 2018. Mayor Nguyen grew up in Orange County, went to Westminster/Bolsa Grande High School, graduated with a Bachelor of Science degree in Engineering at Cal State University, Fullerton and received his Master's Degree from California State University, Long Beach. He is an experienced engineer and a successful businessman who has managed his own business in the City of Westminster for years. In his engineering profession, he worked for Boeing Company, Rockwell International, and B/E Aerospace companies as a Design Engineer, Risk Management Engineer, Project Manager and Senior Manager in the Department of Engineering.

members.name: Mark Nguyen
members.bio: Mark Nguyen was elected to Westminster City Council for District 3 in November 2024. Prior to his election, Mark served as a Planning Commissioner for the City of Westminster. In 2022, Mark was elected by the residents of Westminster and Midway City and currently serves on the Midway City Sanitary District Board of Directors. Mark was named the 2026 Vice Mayor at the December 10, 2025 City Council meeting. Professionally, Mark is a software engineer with a specialization in database administration. His journey began as one of the first refugees to flee Vietnam by boat following the Fall of Saigon. He spent his early years on the Malaysian island of Pulau Bidong and in Nebraska, before moving to Southern California. Mark graduated from UCLA and has been a long-time resident of Westminster where he lives with his wife and children.

members.name: Amy Phan West
members.bio: Born to immigrant parents who fled the Communist regime of Vietnam in 1985, her family's journey included two years in refugee camps before finding asylum in the United States. Councilwoman Phan West is an alumna of Orange Coast College and holds a degree in Education from Cal State University of Long Beach. Currently, Councilwoman Phan West owns an independent rental consortium. She and her husband Jeremy West are raising three young sons.

members.name: Carlos Manzo
members.bio: Council Member Manzo served as Vice Mayor in 2025. He previously served on the Planning Commission for eight years, chairing the commission for two of those years. As an electrical supervisor for a residential homebuilder, he has experience overseeing a large workforce and coordinating with various businesspeople, including developers, contractors and designers. He and his wife Lisa have been active in their four children and four grandchildren's school and extracurricular activities. He focuses on improving public safety and health of residents, believing that quality of life and essential services are important issues. First elected November 2020, re-elected 2024.

members.name: NamQuan Nguyen
members.bio: Council Member Nguyen has previously served this community on the Westminster Traffic Commission. A graduate of UC Irvine, he has a bachelor's degree in Computer Engineering and owns a small business in Westminster. Council Member Nguyen immigrated to this country from Vietnam in 1994 with his immediate family at the age of 20 through the Humanitarian Operation. His focus is on bridging differences among residents, creating an understanding environment, taking good care of seniors, and keeping this All-America City safe.

members.name: Carlos Rodriguez
members.bio: Mayor Carlos Rodriguez brings over two decades of public and private sector experience to the City Council with extensive knowledge of managing a balanced budget, supervising staff, and successfully leading organizations. Mayor Carlos Rodriguez brings a wealth of experience from the public and private sectors to his service on the City Council. He currently serves as the Senior Vice President of the Building Industry Association of Southern California Baldy View Chapter. His professional experience also includes years of collaborating with a variety of businesses and federal, state, and local government agencies while serving as a senior executive of a statewide public affairs firm. Mayor Rodriguez also worked in Sacramento as a senior communications director in the California State Senate, where he advised legislators on media relations and helped craft public information materials. Additionally, he served as an adjunct faculty member and taught communication courses at California State University, Fullerton. Mayor Rodriguez earned his undergraduate degree at California State University, San Bernardino; and his Master of Arts Degree from California State University, Fullerton.

members.name: Peggy Huang
members.bio: Mayor Pro Tem Peggy Huang is passionate about serving the community, with a focus on advocacy for abused, neglected, and developmentally delayed children. She is a Taiwanese native but spent most of her adolescence and young adult years in Northern California. She is a 21-year resident of Yorba Linda. Mayor Pro Tem Huang is a government attorney with vast experience in criminal, civil, and municipal law. As a former Senate Fellow, Mayor Pro Tem Huang worked on the CALFED Bay-Delta project, which involved restoring the Bay-Delta ecosystem and water storage and delivery. As a trial attorney, she prosecuted individuals who abused and neglected clients in facilities licensed by the California Department of Social Services and represented foster children in juvenile court. She was involved in two bills, signed into law, that protected abused and neglected children. In addition, she successfully advocated for the decoupling of the Child Welfare Entitlement (Title IV-B) from the Federal Welfare Reform Act and protecting the Social Security Block Grant (SSBG) from reduction to ensure funding for at-risk and foster children. She received her undergraduate degree at the University of California, Berkeley, and her Juris Doctorate, as well as a specialized certificate of governmental affairs from the University of the Pacific, McGeorge School of Law.

members.name: Tara Campbell
members.bio: Councilwoman Tara Campbell has served on the Yorba Linda City Council since 2016, including serving as Mayor in 2019 making her the youngest female Mayor in California history. As a lifelong Yorba Linda resident, she is a strong advocate for public safety, fiscal responsibility, technology, and communication. Councilwoman Campbell currently works at the County of Orange on issues related to public safety, public health, transportation, infrastructure, and homelessness. Prior to her work at the County of Orange, Councilwoman Campbell worked for the California State Assembly in North Orange County, coordinating special events, including Child Safety Fairs, Small Business Boost Seminars, Senior Health Fairs, and more. Councilwoman Campbell received her Master of Public Administration, along with a Certificate of Public Policy from the University of Southern California (USC). She also received Bachelor of Arts Degrees in Political Science and Broadcast and Digital Journalism from USC. She is proud to bring her education back to her hometown.

members.name: Janice Lim
members.bio: Councilwoman Janice Lim is a seasoned public servant and community advocate with over 20 years of volunteer experience. Committed to preserving the charm and beauty of the city, she brings a unique blend of business acumen, architectural insight, and civic dedication to her role. Councilwoman Lim began her professional journey with a successful career as a senior financial analyst, contributing to major investment projects such as the Century Plaza Towers in Century City and Vista Del Verde in Yorba Linda. After establishing herself in the financial sector, she ventured into entrepreneurship, launching her own small business and collaborating on innovative projects, including a pioneering app that connects social media influencers with brick-and-mortar retailers. Before stepping into public service, Lim also worked as an Account Coordinator for Lancaster Group USA, where she led efforts to introduce designer fragrances to Southern California's retail market. During her postgraduate studies, she served as an Assistant Faculty member in USC's Marshall School of Business, Department of Finance & Business Economics.

members.name: Shivinder Singh
members.bio: Councilmember Shivinder Singh has been a dedicated public servant on Yorba Linda City Commissions since 2017. He began as a Traffic Commissioner and transitioned to the Planning Commission, where he served as Chair in 2024. A devoted family man and servant leader, Councilmember Singh is passionate about making a meaningful and lasting impact in his community. Leveraging extensive expertise in business and technology, including Artificial Intelligence, Active Transportation, and Intelligent Transportation Systems, he brings decades of proven leadership to preserve and enhance Yorba Linda's legacy as the "Land of Gracious Living." Councilmember Singh currently serves as the Chief of the Transportation Management Systems Maintenance Engineering Division for the State of California in Orange County. With over 25 years of distinguished state service, he has played a pivotal role in advancing new technologies, as well as designing, constructing, and maintaining Intelligent Transportation Systems across Southern California's freeways and streets, including in San Bernardino, Riverside, Los Angeles, and Orange Counties. His efforts have ensured the safe, efficient, and effective movement of traffic, people, and goods. Councilmember Singh has actively contributed to securing funding and grants for Capital Improvement projects and collaborated with 34 cities in Orange County and organizations like OCTA, SANBAG, and RCTC. His work on Business Continuity Plans (BCP) has been instrumental in securing resources for California's Transportation program, focusing on Intelligent Transportation and Connected Autonomous Vehicle initiatives statewide—showcasing his commitment to innovation and progress in the transportation field.
